intro: Chaerophyllum karsianum, commonly known as Karsian mountain parsley, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Turkey and the Caucasus. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes familiar plants like carrots and dill, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbellate flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or dry habitats, showcasing its adaptability to harsh environments. It produces small white or pale yellow flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and flies. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and potentially endangered species.
